title: Pagination Pattern
excerpt: Breaking content into manageable pages for improved navigation.
content:
Pagination is a design pattern used to divide content into separate pages. It's commonly used in search results, product listings, and long-form content to make large amounts of information more manageable and easier to navigate.

Key Components

  • Page numbers: Clickable links to specific pages
  • Previous and Next buttons: For sequential navigation
  • First and Last page links: Quick access to the beginning and end
  • Current page indicator: Highlighting the active page
  • Items per page selector: Allowing users to control content density

Best Practices

  1. Clear visual design: Make pagination controls easily identifiable and clickable
  2. Consistent placement: Position pagination controls in a predictable location, typically at the bottom of the content
  3. Show total pages: Display the total number of pages to provide context
  4. Use appropriate page sizes: Balance between showing enough content and not overwhelming the user
  5. Consider 'Load More' alternative: For certain types of content, a 'Load More' button might be more appropriate than traditional pagination
  6. Keyboard accessibility: Ensure pagination can be navigated using keyboard controls

Considerations

  • SEO impact: Implement pagination in a way that search engines can understand and index all pages
  • Mobile design: Adapt pagination for smaller screens, possibly using a simplified version
  • Performance: Optimize page loading to ensure quick transitions between pages

While pagination is a common and often necessary pattern, it's important to consider whether it's the best solution for your specific use case. For some applications, infinite scroll or 'Load More' buttons might provide a better user experience.
